title: Late Arrival After Community Fee Deadline
vignette: A traveler re-enters town after the annual maintenance-fee collection closed and communal purchases had already begun. Should he pay immediately to cover this year or wait until the next cycle?

options.text: Pay immediately, even though the communal purchase has begun.
Wait until next year's cycle.

title: Paying for a Neighbor Anonymously
vignette: Ruth wants to cover her poor neighbor's community fee without informing him.

options.text: Do so secretly; his obligation is now covered.
He must contribute knowingly for it to count as his civic duty.

title: Coin-Swap Premium: Personal or Communal?
vignette: Officials exchange various currencies for the standard coins accepted at the civic center, adding a small service premium. May the treasurer keep the fee as compensation, or must all proceeds go to the center's fund?

options.text: All proceeds belong to the central fund.
The fee compensates for the effort and risk.

title: Splitting One Coin for Two Donors
vignette: Two brothers have only a single large coin to pay their two small community fees.

options.text: Give the coin jointly on behalf of both.
Each must give a separate, correct-value coin later.

title: Using Surplus Fees for Protective Walls
vignette: Fee collections exceeded the yearly operating costs for the civic center. Leaders propose spending the surplus on perimeter security walls. Is this permitted once core services are funded, or must it be restricted to the center's primary activities only?

options.text: Permitted, as protecting the facility is a valid use of funds.
Forbidden; surplus must be saved for next year's core services.

title: Overpaying the Obligation
vignette: Levi mistakenly places two coins in the community chest instead of one.

options.text: Treat the extra as a voluntary gift to the community.
Retrieve the surplus amount at once.

title: Using Civic Funds to Dig Emergency Wells
vignette: A severe drought threatens the city. May administrators redirect unallocated civic center funds to drill fresh water wells, provided regular services continue uninterrupted?

options.text: Allowed, as public health is a priority.
Forbiddenâ€”funds are only for the designated civic center services.

title: Accepting Coins from Non-Residents
vignette: Foreign visitors offer donations toward the daily upkeep of the civic center.

options.text: Decline; communal upkeep must be funded by residents.
Accept the help to foster goodwill.

title: Lost-and-Found Donation Coin
vignette: A coin earmarked for the community fee rolled under furniture and surfaced months later, after the annual collection. Should it now enter the current fund or be diverted to a general charity?

options.text: Deposit it in the current year's community fund.
Use it for a different public charity instead.

title: Pressuring Hold-Outs to Contribute
vignette: Some residents refuse the mandatory civic upkeep fee. Should officials apply coercive measures (fines, liens) or rely solely on gentle persuasion?

options.text: Apply legal pressure; everyone must contribute their share.
Persuade gently without compulsion.

title: Exchanging Small Change from the Treasury
vignette: A senior official needs coins of a lesser value for personal expenses.

options.text: He may swap his larger coin with coins from the community treasury for the exact same value.
He must not conduct personal transactions with treasury assets.

title: Theft of the Donation Chest
vignette: Thieves steal the civic-center cash box mid-year. Should the community replenish it immediately from other municipal reserves, or wait for next year's round of contributions?

options.text: The community must replace it from other funds to ensure services continue.
Leave it empty until new fees arrive next year.

title: Replacing a Stolen Donation Box
vignette: Thieves steal the community center's box of coins.

options.text: The community must replace the funds from other reserves.
Wait until new fees are collected next year.

title: Counting Coins on Rest Day
vignette: Officials continue tallying the collected community fees after sundown on Friday, the start of a community rest day.

options.text: Stop the count; it dishonors the rest day.
Finish quickly to secure the coins and complete the audit.

title: Label-Control for Annual Livestock Purchases
vignette: Animals bought with this year's civic funds must stay distinct from last year's stock for audit purposes. Must staff tag each animal before delivery, or is verbal intent sufficient for the records?

options.text: Tag them clearly before delivery for accurate accounting.
No need for labels; intent is enough for the records.
